PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person experiencing this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may be impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use your best judgment in answering each question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1921, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

A VOTE OF APPRECIATION TO THE PERSON REPRESENTATIVE OF THE UNIVERSITY OF SASKATCHEWAN

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has experienced the same experiences as another. Some of the questions will not apply to your experience; others may be impossible for you to answer so don't worry about answering blank spaces. If you can't answer a question, just leave it blank.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1931, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experiences of the pioneer years or has been born in this province or its' neighbors.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

34. Did many people move away from your district prior to 1942? If so, what reasons did they have for moving?

Just a very few left this district. Mostly single men who had to get a stake.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? If so, why?

No, not really, there was no rush this time.

The people have held on, though it was pretty hard.

There was a steady stream of people from the south, pouring through Rocktown on Highway 6.

I think I had the first automobile and was employed by Junior Warden when the Mason Lodge was organized. By your Master, Wallace Macgregor, Lewis Warden, and myself.

39. Any other comments?

Port town got its name from a homesteader who farmed a mile NW of Rocktown. He was an old man, and was known as Brad Rose. He and his wife were named by a farmer who had lived in a house near New Zealand. His name was named by a family who lived at a stopping place on the Old Bone Trail, by the name of Hanoi. Many schools are named after the early settlers.
